literal: Grandmother said it ambiguously.
meaning: It’s very doubtful, undefined; it remains to be seen.
equivalents: We’ll see what we’ll see; maybe rain or maybe snow, maybe yes or maybe no

literal: To run with one’s tongue hanging out.
meaning: To run fast without pausing for breath, to be breathless from running.
equivalents: To run as fast as one’s legs can carry one; to run at a breakneck pace

literal: Without a snag, without any unevenness or roughness.
meaning: Without any obstruction, difficulty or complication; smoothly.
equivalents: Without a hitch; like clockwork

literal: A white crow.
meaning: Someone unusual, extraordinary; not like others; an outsider.
equivalents: Rara avis

literal: To keep striking the same spot.
meaning: To concentrate one’s efforts on one thing in seeking to attain a specific goal.

literal: To well up, to bubble.
meaning: To be in full operation; to proceed in a lively manner.
equivalents: To boil over; to be in full swing

literal: To beat against the ice like a fish.
meaning: To struggle desperately.
equivalents: To pull the devil by the tail

literal: To take something from the ceiling.
meaning: To allege something without sufficient factual grounds; to say something without thinking, at random.
equivalents: To make something up; to talk through one’s hat

literal: To take oneself by the mind.
meaning: To stop behaving imprudently; to become sensible, reasonable.
equivalents: To come to one’s senses

literal: To throw pebbles into someone’s kitchen-garden.
meaning: To allude to someone with mild derision; to make an implied criticism.
equivalents: To give someone a dig

literal: To throw words to the wind.
meaning: Not to care what one says; to speak at random or idly.
equivalents: To talk to the wind; to waste one’s breath.

literal: To throw one’s words about
meaning: To speak irresponsibly, to use words lightly.

literal: To cast a shadow on someone/something.
meaning: To put someone or something in a bad light; to cast suspicion on someone; to blacken someone’s reputation.
equivalents: To cast a slur on someone’s reputation

literal: To be between the sledge-hammer and the anvil.
meaning: To be caught between two equally serious evils or dangers.
equivalents: To be between the devil and the deep blue sea

literal: To be not in one’s personal plate.
meaning: To be not quite oneself, to be not quite at ease, to feel uneasy.
equivalents: To be out of sorts

literal: To be not of the timid dozen.
meaning: Not one to scare easily; not easily frightened, not a coward.

literal: To be unfit for the courtyard.
meaning: To be unsuitable, to be unwanted, not meeting certain requirements; to be an outsider.
equivalents: Not to fit in

literal: To be not in one’s own place.
meaning: To be unsuited to the position one fills, to be a misfit.
equivalents: A round peg in a square hole

literal: To be dressed as if straight from the pin.
meaning: To be dressed in a brand-new suit, dress, etc.
equivalents: To be dressed up; as neat as a new pin

literal: To be under someone’s shoe.
meaning: To be under someone’s predominant influence, to be in complete subjection (usually said of a man who is dominated by his wife).
equivalents: To get someone by the short hairs; to be hen-pecked; to be under someone’s thumb

literal: To be bound by one’s word.
meaning: To be faithful in keeping one’s promise.

literal: To throw everything into one heap.
meaning: To put together, to mix up indiscriminately; to lump everything together.

head_ru: ВАЛИТЬ С БОЛЬНОЙ ГОЛОВЫ НА ЗДОРОВУЮ
transliteration: valit’ s bol’noy golovy na zdorovuyu
literal: To shift something from an ailing head onto the one that doesn’t ail.
meaning: To blame someone else for one’s own fault.
equivalents: To lay one’s blame at someone else’s door; to shift the blame on someone

literal: To fall out of one’s hands.
meaning: Something doesn’t go well because one is awkward, clumsy, doesn’t feel like doing it, or doesn’t have his heart in it.

literal: To stew in one’s own juice.
meaning: To keep solitary or apart from other people making no use of other people’s knowledge and experience; to work solely by oneself without contact with others; to avoid social relations.
equivalents: To be aloof; to keep to oneself

literal: To hang one’s nose.
meaning: To be crest-fallen, discouraged, despondent; to look dejected.

literal: To breathe freely.
meaning: To feel relieved of one’s cares or troubles.
equivalents: To give a sigh of relief

literal: To take the word.
meaning: To rise to speak in a debate at one’s own request or initiative.
equivalents: To take the floor

literal: Seen as if it were on the palm of one’s hand
meaning: Spread before the eyes, in plain sight easy to see or comprehend.
equivalents: As plain as the nose on your face

literal: A bird is seen by its flight.
meaning: You can judge a person by his actions and behaviour.

literal: Written with a pitchfork on the water.
meaning: It’s uncertain, not defined, vague; it may or may not come off.
equivalents: It’s still all up in the air

literal: To be hanging on the telephone.
meaning: To talk incessantly on the telephone, to spend hours on the telephone.
equivalents: To sit on the phone

literal: To plait ropes out of someone.
meaning: To have a strong influence on someone; to have a person entirely subservient to one’s will.
equivalents: To twist someone around one’s little finger

literal: To fall in love up to one’s ears.
meaning: To be deeply enamoured of someone.
equivalents: To be head over heels in love

literal: To lead someone by the nose.
meaning: To deceive, delude, mislead someone; to make promises and not keep them.
equivalents: To make a fool of someone; to pull/draw the wool over someone’s eyes; to lead someone on

literal: You couldn’t split them apart with water.
meaning: To be very good friends, close to each other; inseparable from each other; to be always together.
equivalents: As thick as thieves

literal: He wouldn’t muddy the water.
meaning: One who has extremely demure expression and manner; one who is quiet, meek, gentle.
equivalents: He wouldn’t hurt a fly; he looks as if butter wouldn’t melt in his mouth

literal: Here’s where the dog is buried.
meaning: That’s the main reason, the main point; that’s where the problem lies.
equivalents: That’s the heart of the matter; that’s the crux of the matter

literal: To take root.
meaning: To become permanently and firmly established; to become attached to something; to get fully accustomed to something.

literal: To meet someone or something with bayonets.
meaning: To give a hostile reception to someone or something.

literal: To step into formation.
meaning: To come into operation, to become operative.

literal: Not to blow into one’s moustache.
meaning: Not to care at all; not to show any sign of emotion.
equivalents: Not to give a damn/a hang; not to turn a hair

literal: To knock someone out of the saddle.
meaning: To deprive someone of his position or role in society; to undermine someone’s confidence in something completely; to disturb someone’s peace of mind.

literal: To lead someone out of himself.
meaning: To exasperate, irritate someone.
equivalents: To drive someone out of his wits/mind; to put someone beside himself

literal: To take out of formation.
meaning: To disable something, to put something out of operation.

literal: To conduct someone out onto pure water.
meaning: To bring someone’s misdeeds to light; to expose someone.
equivalents: To show someone in his true colours; to unmask.

literal: To come out of oneself.
meaning: To be carried away by excitement; to lose control of oneself; to be wrought up.
equivalents: To lose one’s temper; to fly off the handle.

literal: To step out of formation.
meaning: To be disabled, to become unserviceable; to break down; to be put out of action.

literal: To come out of the water dry.
meaning: To escape deserved punishment; to come out with one’s reputation unblemished.
equivalents: To come out unscathed; to get off scot-free.

literal: To fly through the chimney
meaning: To come to ruin financially, to go bankrupt; to have no money at all.
equivalents: To go bust/smash.

literal: To bear something on one’s own shoulders.
meaning: To take the whole burden of something; to endure the stress or strain of a difficult undertaking.
equivalents: To bear the brunt of something

literal: To carry the rubbish out of one’s hut.
meaning: To let the outside world know about one’s private troubles, grievances, quarrels, conduct that might be regarded as disreputable; to utter abroad affairs not meant for the public ear.
equivalents: To wash one’s dirty linen in public; to tell tales out of school

literal: To grow in someone’s eyes.
meaning: To rise in someone’s esteem; to grow or improve in someone’s opinion.

literal: To suck something out of one’s finger.
meaning: To allege something which has no foundation in actual fact, absolutely groundless; to fabricate.
equivalents: To make something up; to spin something out of thin air.

literal: To stretch oneself into a string.
meaning: To stand stiffly erect; to stand at attention.

literal: One’s eyes are running in different directions.
meaning: One doesn’t know what to look at first; one is dazzled by the sight of so many things; one is unable to concentrate on one thing.

literal: One’s eyes have lit up.
meaning: One desires something earnestly; one is looking longingly or desiringly at something.
equivalents: To be dying for

literal: To speak to someone’s hand.
meaning: To say something at the wrong time; to disturb someone when he is concentrating on something; to distract someone by talking.
equivalents: To put someone off.

literal: It is burning in one’s hands.
meaning: The work is being done quickly, energetically, deftly; the work is going fine.
equivalents: Someone has clever hands; someone is working like lightning

literal: To tease the geese.
meaning: To irritate, to annoy someone (often without purpose or reason); to provoke ill feelings.

literal: To give someone the change.
meaning: To retaliate as vigorously as one is attacked; to give as good as one got; to return insult for insult.
equivalents: To answer in kind

literal: You can’t go farther.
meaning: Things couldn’t be worse; that’s the end of it; that’s the limit.

literal: Two boots make a pair.
meaning: They are alike; (usually with reference to disposition, tastes, conduct, etc.); they are well matched; they deserve each other; one is no better than the other.
equivalents: They make a pair; birds of one feather; not a pin to choose between them

literal: To make an elephant out of a fly.
meaning: To exaggerate the importance of a small matter.
equivalents: To make a mountain out of a molehill

literal: To make the weather.
meaning: To determine the course of events, to affect a matter directly; to have a decisive influence on a matter.

literal: To do something with one’s eyes closed
meaning: To do something without thinking, carelessly, rashly.

literal: To do something with one’s sleeves lowered.
meaning: To do something carelessly without paying attention to it; to fail to tend properly to affairs; to do something in a slipshod manner.
equivalents: To let things slide

literal: The hens don’t peck at the money.
meaning: One has plenty of money.
equivalents: Rolling in money

literal: To keep in a black body.
meaning: To ill-treat, to treat someone roughly; to hold in subjection.

literal: To keep a stone inside one’s shirt.
meaning: To secretly bear a grudge against someone; to nurse a grievance; to harbour thoughts of revenge; to have evil intentions.

literal: To keep one’s nose to the wind.
meaning: To adapt to circumstances, unscrupulously altering one’s convictions or behaviour; to adjust to the situation.
equivalents: To trim one’s sails to the wind

literal: To keep one’s ear sharp.
meaning: To behave circumspectly, to act with caution; to be on guard; to mistrust someone.
equivalents: To watch one’s step; to be on the qui vive; to keep one’s eyes peeled.

literal: To bring to a white heat.
meaning: To drive someone to a frenzy, to infuriate, to rouse to fury; to make someone lose his self-control.

literal: Till one falls down.
meaning: To the point of exhaustion, till one drops.

literal: One’s soul is open (unbuttoned).
meaning: To be frank, sincere candid, straightforward.
equivalents: Open-hearted.

literal: One’s soul is not in its place.
meaning: To be anxious; to feel uneasy.

literal: There is still some gunpowder in the powder-flasks.
meaning: Still full of vim and vigour; still able to fight or to do something important.
equivalents: We are not licked yet

literal: To ride as a hare.
meaning: To travel without paying for a ticket.

literal: To wait by the sea for the weather.
meaning: To indulge in vain hopes without taking any steps to realize them; to waste one’s time neglecting one’s opportunities.
equivalents: To let the grass grow under one’s feet.

literal: To live soul and soul together.
meaning: To live in peace, harmony, concord or perfect amity with someone.

literal: To live on a broad foot.
meaning: To live in luxury; to live sumptuously, sparing no expense.
equivalents: To live like a lord; to live in grand style

literal: To live humming a tune.
meaning: To live in comfortable circumstances; to live happily.
equivalents: To be in clover

literal: To lose one’s way among three pines.
meaning: To fail to find a solution to a simple problem; to fail to comprehend something elementary.
equivalents: To lose one’s way in broad daylight.

literal: To peep into someone’s soul
meaning: To try to fathom someone’s innermost thoughts; to try to find out what is in someone else’s heart.

literal: To talk someone’s teeth.
meaning: To evade the issue with irrelevant talk.
equivalents: To put someone off with fair words.

literal: To give pepper.
meaning: To rate someone soundly and severely; to punish someone.
equivalents: To give it hot to someone; to make it hot for someone.

literal: To graze a raw place.
meaning: To excite greatly, to thrill; to stir someone’s self-esteem or pride.
equivalents: To cut/sting to the quick

literal: To creep into someone’s soul.
meaning: To creep or steal into one’s mind (said of thoughts or feelings)

literal: To get locked up in one’s own self.
meaning: To become less sociable and more reserved; to withdraw from the society of one’s fellows; to retire into oneself.
equivalents: To shut oneself up; to withdraw/retire into one’s shell.

literal: To underfeed the little worm.
meaning: To have a little to eat.
equivalents: To have a snack; to have a bite; to take the edge off one’s hunger.

literal: To make a notch on one’s nose.
meaning: To remember something firmly, forever.
equivalents: Bear it in mind; put that into your pipe and smoke it.

literal: He/she doesn’t snatch stars from the sky.
meaning: One isn’t a remarkable person; one is a person of average or mediocre abilities.
equivalents: He won’t set the Thames/world on fire

literal: To know the measure.
meaning: To know one’s limits; to be moderate; to know when to stop.

literal: To probe the ground.
meaning: To try cautiously to discover someone’s inclinations, to test the views of others, to sound out one’s chances of success beforehand.
equivalents: To find out how the things stand; to explore the ground; to put forth/throw out a feeler.

literal: To walk wherever one’s eyes are looking.
meaning: To wander aimlessly; to go wherever one’s feet will carry one.

literal: Made of the same dough.
meaning: They are just about the same in disposition, tastes, etc.
equivalents: Two of a kind; the same breed; cut from the same cloth; birds of one feather.

literal: To search for yesterday.
meaning: To waste time on a hopeless quest.
equivalents: To go on a wild-goose chase

head_ru: ИСКАТЬ / НЕ НАЙТИ ДНЁМ С ОГНЁМ
literal: To search for someone or something by day with a light
meaning: To seek in vain; to look hard for someone or something with little chance of finding; it’s nowhere to be found.
equivalents: You will not find it in a month of Sundays; you can’t get it for love or money.

literal: Sparks began to pour out of one’s eyes.
meaning: A sensation of light flashing before one’s eyes, caused by a blow in the face or on the head.
equivalents: To see stars

literal: To spoil all the music
meaning: To upset a plan; to disrupt the procedure; to cause disturbance.
equivalents: To upset someone’s apple-cart; to play the very devil with something.

literal: Doesn’t wiggle an ear.
meaning: One doesn’t pay the least attention to something; one doesn’t react at all; one deliberately shows indifference.
equivalents: Without batting an eyelid

literal: Look for the wind in the field.
meaning: It’s gone without leaving a trace; it’s nowhere to be found and it can never be returned.
equivalents: To look for a needle in a haystack; to go on a wild-goose chase.

literal: As if one had swallowed an arshin (a ruler one arshin in length equivalent to 28 inches)
meaning: Unnaturally erect, quite stiff; rigid, upright in bearing.
equivalents: As stiff as a poker.

literal: As if without the hands.
meaning: To feel quite helpless without something or someone.

literal: Just like at the chemist’s.
meaning: Exactly, precisely; just so, just right.
equivalents: To a T.

literal: Like having looked into the water.
meaning: As if something had been known beforehand; someone was able to foresee future events.
equivalents: He must have second sight

literal: As if lowered into the water.
meaning: Dejected, downcast, depressed, crest-fallen.
equivalents: To be down in the chops/mouth

literal: As if a mountain had fallen off one’s shoulders.
meaning: Someone is relieved of anxiety, doubt, cares.
equivalents: A load off one’s mind

literal: Like two times two is four.
meaning: Easy to see or comprehend; as plain or clear as can be; obvious to everyone.
equivalents: As plain as a pikestaff; as plain as the nose on your face.

literal: Like two drops of water.
meaning: To bear a very close resemblance; to be exactly alike.
equivalents: As like as two peas in a pod; not a pin to choose between them.

literal: As though behind a stone wall.
meaning: To be well protected; to be very secure; to be perfectly safe.
equivalents: As safe as houses.

literal: As if grown up from under the ground.
meaning: Someone appeared all of a sudden, unexpectedly, from nowhere.
equivalents: Out of the blue.

literal: As if out of the horn of plenty.
meaning: In great plenty, in abundance

literal: As if a cow has licked it off with its tongue.
meaning: Someone or something has disappeared without a trace.
equivalents: To vanish/disappear into thin air.

literal: As far off as heaven from earth.
meaning: To differ essentially, sharply, strongly.
equivalents: There is a world of difference between them

literal: Like throwing peas against the wall.
meaning: To say something to which not the slightest attention is paid (often uttered in irritation).
equivalents: You might as well talk to a brick wall/to the wind

literal: Like sliding on oil.
meaning: Things are going well, smoothly, swimmingly, without any obstruction or complication.
equivalents: Like clockwork; without a hitch

literal: As if played from music.
meaning: To accomplish something without any difficulty, efficiently, according to a carefully thought-out plan; to perform something with clockwork precision.

literal: As if taken off by the hand.
meaning: Suddenly gone, completely disappeared as if by magic (usually said of pain or fatigue)

literal: Like a fish in water.
meaning: To feel free and easy; to be in suitable or satisfying surroundings; to find something natural and easy to do.
equivalents: To feel in one’s element; to feel quite at home; to take to something like a duck to water; like a fish in water

literal: Like snow onto the head.
meaning: To appear or arrive suddenly and unexpectedly.
equivalents: To come like a bolt from/out of the blue; to drop from the clouds.

literal: Like the devil running away from the incense.
meaning: To get rid of or shun someone or something.
equivalents: To avoid someone or something like the plague

literal: A stone has fallen off one’s heart.
meaning: Someone feels relieved of a burden of an unpleasant, sad or oppressive feeling.
equivalents: A load off one’s mind

literal: Not to leave one stone upon another stone.
meaning: To criticize something severely by pointing out the weak points or faults; to utterly demolish an argument.
equivalents: To pull/take something to pieces; to make mincemeat of something.

literal: To be rolling like cheese in butter.
meaning: To be comfortably off.
equivalents: To live in clover; to live on the fat of the land; to live like a king.

literal: You won’t cook kasha with someone.
meaning: You can’t get on with someone; you won’t get anywhere with someone; it’s difficult to work with someone.

literal: Thrown into a heat.
meaning: He/she becomes extremely agitated or anxious; he/she feels hot all over.

literal: To peck with one’s nose.
meaning: To nod; to be drowsy.

literal: When the crayfish whistles.
meaning: No one knows when; never.
equivalents: When pigs fly; when two Fridays come together

literal: Something the cat cried out.
meaning: Very little; practically nothing; nothing to speak of.

literal: Cats are scratching on one’s soul.
meaning: To be melancholy, sad, depressed; to be anxious about something.
equivalents: To be sick at heart; to have the blues.

head_ru: КРИЧАТЬ о чём-либо НА ВСЕХ ПЕРЕКРЁСТКАХ
literal: To shout about something at all cross-roads.
meaning: To announce something in the most public manner possible; to make something generally known to a wide public; to talk constantly about something.
equivalents: To cry/shout from the house-tops.

literal: Blood with milk.
meaning: Someone with fresh complexion, in the best of health; one who looks quite well.
equivalents: The very picture of health.

head_ru: КТО В ЛЕС, КТО ПО ДРОВА
transliteration: kto v l’es kto po drova
literal: Some to the forest, some to gather firewood.
meaning: A phrase expressing lack of coordination or harmony (often said of singing or playing musical instruments)

literal: To bite one’s own elbows.
meaning: To be deeply vexed; to be upset over an irreparable loss of someone or something.
equivalents: To cry over spilt milk; to kick oneself over a lost opportunity.

literal: A light hand.
meaning: Someone is known to bring luck to any kind of undertaking.

literal: Easy on the ascent.
meaning: Always ready and willing to go somewhere or do something.
equivalents: Quick off the mark; quick on one’s toes.

literal: The ice has begun to break.
meaning: A beginning has been made; things are moving.

literal: To climb into the bottle.
meaning: To be carried away by excitement, to lose self-control, to become suddenly or violently angry (usually without reason, over a mere trifle).
equivalents: To fly off the handle; to blow one’s top.

literal: To climb into someone’s soul.
meaning: To try to find out someone’s innermost feelings, thoughts, intentions; to win someone’s favour or confidence.
equivalents: To worm oneself into someone’s favour/confidence

literal: To climb out of one’s skin.
meaning: To make a great effort; to do one’s utmost, to try one’s hardest.
equivalents: To lean/bend over backwards; to go out of one’s way; to go all out.

literal: To pour as from a pail.
meaning: To rain heavily.
equivalents: It rains cats and dogs

literal: To catch something in flight.
meaning: To be quick to comprehend or to learn something; to grasp something easily, at once.
equivalents: To be quick on the uptake

literal: To catch one at one’s word.
meaning: To make someone do or promise to do what he said he would do.
equivalents: To take someone at his word.

literal: To burst like a soap-bubble.
meaning: Said of something that proves to be unstable, ephemeral or easily destroyed.

literal: A master at all hands.
meaning: To be good at anything one undertakes; to show talent in anything one turns his hand to; a versatile worker.
equivalents: A jack-of-all-trades

literal: To wave one’s hand at something or someone.
meaning: To stop doing something or dealing with someone; not to care what happens; to give something up as a lost or hopeless cause.

literal: A bear stepped on someone’s ear.
meaning: Someone has no ear for music; someone is quite tone-deaf.

literal: A bear’s service.
meaning: A well-meant action having the opposite effect; clumsy assistance causing only more problems; a dubious benefit conferred on someone; a disservice.

literal: To exchange a cuckoo for a hawk.
meaning: To select the worst from among the worse; to be out of one’s reckoning; to miscalculate.
equivalents: To back the wrong horse.

literal: To measure by one’s own arshin.
meaning: To judge others by oneself; to apply one’s own standard to others.
equivalents: To measure another’s corn by one’s own bushel

literal: The world is cramped.
meaning: You may unexpectedly run across a person you know anywhere.
equivalents: It’s a small world.

literal: Much water has flowed away.
meaning: That was long ago; much has happened since; much has changed since.
equivalents: A lot of water has flowed under the bridge since

literal: The sea is knee-deep.
meaning: One is unconcerned; one couldn’t care less; one is absolutely reckless.
equivalents: Devil-may-care

literal: To wind something on one’s moustache
meaning: To observe something silently; to make a mental note of something.
equivalents: Bite on that

literal: My hut is on the periphery.
meaning: This has nothing to do with me; it’s no business/concern of mine.

literal: To muddy the water.
meaning: To deliberately muddle matters; to stir up trouble; to confuse things.

literal: Mice’s fussing.
meaning: Pointless fussing over trifles.

literal: To strengthen one’s hand.
meaning: To practice so as to acquire skill, to develop a good technique in something; to become a practiced hand at something; to give oneself a steady hand.
equivalents: To get the knack of something

literal: To fill one’s mouth with water.
meaning: To remain silent; not to utter a word.
equivalents: To keep mum

literal: To sharpen the skis.
meaning: To flee, to run away.
equivalents: To take to one’s heels; to show a clean pair of heels.

literal: To get stuck in one’s teeth.
meaning: To have had more than enough; to be sick and tired of something.
equivalents: To set one’s teeth on edge.

literal: To rely on someone as on a rock mountain.
meaning: To rely fully on someone or something.

literal: To blow up one’s lips.
meaning: To be angry, to take offence wearing a sulky expression; to express dissatisfaction or displeasure; to be in a disagreeable mood.
equivalents: To pout

literal: To press on all the buttons.
meaning: To use every direct or indirect means in order to attain a goal; to exert personal and private influence on a matter affecting oneself or others.
equivalents: To pull wires/strings.

literal: To press all the pedals.
meaning: To do everything in one’s power to carry out a task, a promise, etc.
equivalents: To go all out

literal: To find oneself.
meaning: To find and realize one’s vocation, calling; to determine one’s aptitude, bent or inclinations.

literal: To break up some firewood
meaning: To commit follies; to make a mess of things.

literal: To soap someone’s neck.
meaning: To reprimand or criticize someone sharply; to give someone a good rating.
equivalents: To haul someone over the coals; to give someone a dressing-down.

literal: To let the fog in.
meaning: To obscure the issue; to befog something; to confuse things; to try to mislead someone

literal: To salt someone.
meaning: To spite; to cause someone annoyance; to do someone a bad turn.

literal: To be at freezing-point.
meaning: To remain in the same state or condition without developing or progressing; to be at a standstill.

literal: The scythe has struck a stone.
meaning: A clash of conflicting personalities, interests, opinions, etc.
equivalents: One has met his match; diamond cut diamond

literal: One won’t see it as his own ears.
meaning: One will never see, get or possess something or someone.
equivalents: You won’t see hide nor hair of something or someone; you have to kiss it good-bye.

literal: Not to see the white world.
meaning: One is so burdened with work or cares that he has no peace, no rest and can’t lead a normal life.

literal: Not beyond the hills.
meaning: Something is about to happen very soon.
equivalents: Near at hand.

head_ru: НЕ ЛЕЗТЬ ЗА СЛОВОМ В КАРМАН
transliteration: n’e l’ezt’ za slovom v karman
literal: Not to climb for a word into one’s pocket.
meaning: To be quick to respond, to answer promptly and well; not to be at a loss for words.
equivalents: To have a ready/ quick tongue.

literal: Dumb as a fish.
meaning: Someone says very little or nothing; reserved, uncommunicative.
equivalents: Close/dumb as an oyster; silent as a grave; tight-lipped

literal: If not by washing, then by mangling.
meaning: To try to get something; to annoy or vex someone by any means, right or wrong.
equivalents: By hook or by crook.

literal: To be extremely anxious, discontented; to fret; to worry;
meaning: to be extremely anxious; discontented; to fret; to worry; not to know what to do with oneself.

literal: Not to smell gun-powder.
meaning: Not to have been in combat.

literal: Not to strike the mud with one’s face.
meaning: To maintain one’s dignity; to acquit oneself well; not to disgrace oneself; to try to appear at one’s best.
equivalents: To put one’s best foot forward; to make a good showing.

literal: That’s not a pound of raisins
meaning: It’s not a trifle; it’s not to be regarded as negligible or unimportant; it’s no light,matter; it’s no joke.
equivalents: It’s not to be sneezed/sniffled at

literal: Having an unclean hand.
meaning: Inclined to stealing, swindling or cheating; dishonest, underhanded.

literal: Not to feel one’s feet under oneself.
meaning: To be very happy, to be highly delighted
equivalents: To be beside oneself with joy; to tread/walk on air

literal: Neither two nor one and a half.
meaning: Defies classification; neither good rior bad neither one thing nor the other.

literal: Not for any gingerbread.
meaning: Not for anything; not on any account.
equivalents: Not for the world; not on your life

head_ru: НИ К СЕЛУ НИ К ГОРОДУ
transliteration: ni k s’elu ni k gorodu
literal: Neither to the village nor to the town.
meaning: Beside the point, out of place; for no apparent reason; quite irrelevantly
equivalents: Neither here nor there

literal: It doesn’t look like anything.
meaning: Very bad; unthinkable; unheard of; like nothing on earth; that won’t do; that’s no good at all.

literal: Neither down nor feather.
meaning: Good luck!

literal: A sharp knife.
meaning: Something extremely unpleasant or painful; something is the source of annoyance, grief, etc.
equivalents: Gall and wormwood; this is sheer agony/hell.

literal: The number won’t pass through.
meaning: That won’t do; you can’t get away with it.
equivalents: Nothing doing; that trick won’t work; that won’t wash.

literal: To carry water in a sieve.
meaning: To do something useless; to waste time.
equivalents: To plough the sand

literal: As needed as last year’s snow
meaning: Here is no need to.

literal: To promise mountains of gold
meaning: To promise someone a fortune; to make extravagant promises.
equivalents: To promise the moon

literal: To knock against the thresholds.
meaning: To go frequently somewhere trying to obtain something; to apply or petition with dogged persistence.
equivalents: To haunt someone’s threshold; to camp on someone’s doorstep

literal: To apply to the wrong address.
meaning: To come to the wrong person or place to get what one requires.
equivalents: To come to the wrong shop

literal: Alone as a finger.
meaning: All alone in the world; all by oneself; without kinfolk.

literal: One foot’s here, the other’s there.
meaning: To go and fetch, to run and fetch; to do something very quickly, with lightning speed.

literal: A berry from the same field.
meaning: They look alike; they are similar in disposition, tastes, etc.; they are well matched; they deserve each other; one is no better than the other.
equivalents: Not a pin to choose between them; cut from the same cloth; birds of one feather

literal: To find oneself between the sky and the earth.
To plunge headlong
meaning: To become utterly absorbed/engrossed in something; to be deeply immersed, irrevocably involved.
equivalents: To be up to one’s ears in something; to throw oneself in something

literal: To lower one’s hands
meaning: To lose interest; to become disappointed, depressed; to be disheartened
equivalents: To lose heart

literal: To leave someone with his nose.
meaning: To leave someone without something he had hoped for; to make a fool of someone; to trick someone.
equivalents: To leave someone holding the bag

literal: To be left on the beans
meaning: To be left without something one has hoped for; to be out in one’s reckoning; to get nothing for one’s pains; to be left with nothing.
equivalents: To be left holding the bag

literal: To be left at the broken wash-tub.
meaning: To be left with nothing, having lost everything one had; to be no better off than when one started.
equivalents: To be back at the bottom of the ladder

literal: To put aside for a black day
meaning: To save or reserve something (usually one’s income) for time of trouble, for bad times.
equivalents: To save/put by for a rainy day

literal: To discover America.
meaning: To say something that everyone has long been aware of; to say or explain something that is already well known to everyone; to retail stale news.
equivalents: The Dutch have taken Holland; Queen Ann is dead

literal: To open one’s soul / heart to someone.
meaning: To tell someone frankly of one’s innermost thoughts or feelings.
equivalents: To lay bare one’s heart

literal: To show one’s cards
meaning: To stop making secrets of one’s plans or intentions; to reveal candidly all one’s aims
equivalents: To lay / put one’s cards on the table; to show one’s hand

literal: Cf. To lay /put one’s
meaning: cards on the table; to show one’s hand.
equivalents: That's how it all started.

literal: Not to strike one finger against another.
meaning: To be idle; not to stir oneself; not to make the slightest effort to attain one’s goal.
equivalents: Not to raise/lift a finger. Not to hurt a fly.

literal: A staff with two ends.
meaning: Something that can have pleasant and unpleasant consequences; something that can bring good as well as harm.
equivalents: A double-edged/two-edged weapon; it cuts both ways.

literal: Don’t put your finger in his/ her mouth.
meaning: Someone is not to be trifled with; with this man one must be scrupulously exact; one must be on one’s guard with him because he is likely to take advantage of another’s false step.

literal: Not to touch anyone with one’s finger
meaning: Not to do anyone any harm; not to hit someone.
equivalents: Not to hurt a fly.

literal: The first swallow.
meaning: The first portent of something.

literal: To bend the stick.
meaning: To go beyond the appointed or accepted limit; to go to the extreme; to go too far; to overdo something.
equivalents: To overshoot the mark.

literal: To pour something from one empty vessel into another.
meaning: To waste time on something useless; to waste time in useless debate; to engage in idle chatter.
equivalents: To mill the wind; to beat the air.

literal: To break oneself in two
meaning: To master oneself; to conquer one’s temper; to change one’s behaviour, character, habits; to restrain or suppress one’s feelings; to overcome oneself or something in oneself.

literal: To wash someone’s bones.
meaning: To gossip, to say spiteful things about someone; to find detailed faults in a person.
equivalents: To pick/pull someone to pieces

literal: To overfill the cup of patience
meaning: To bring someone to the end of his endurance or patience; to exasperate someone; to be at the end of one’s tether
equivalents: The last straw; to break the camel’s back

literal: One’s song has been sung.
meaning: One is near his end; one is ruined; it’s all done with him; he’s done for.
equivalents: Someone’s goose is cooked

literal: To swim like an axe.
meaning: To be a poor swimmer or not to be able to swim at all.
equivalents: To swim like a stone/like a tailor’s goose

literal: To weep into someone’s waistcoast
meaning: To bewail one’s fate seeking sympathy or consolation.
equivalents: To cry on someone’s shoulder

literal: To spit at the ceiling
meaning: To do nothing at all; to be idle.
equivalents: To fritter away the time; to sit twiddling

literal: To crawl like a tortoise.
meaning: To go very slowly; to drag oneself along; to trudge.
equivalents: To go at a crawl; to move at a snail’s pace

literal: To pursue two different aims simultaneously
meaning: To run after two hares.

literal: While the tracks are hot.
meaning: Without losing time; immediately, directly after some event.
equivalents: To let no grass grow under one’s feet

literal: To bring someone up to a monastery.
meaning: To put someone into a difficult position; to put someone in a tight spot; to cause someone much trouble.

literal: Under-water rocks.
meaning: A difficulty which is hard to foresee; a hidden obstacle; a snag.

literal: Under a hot hand.
meaning: One does something while still angry, excited, disturbed.
equivalents: In the heat of the moment.

literal: To lay a pig near someone
meaning: To do a vile thing to someone on the sly.
equivalents: To play a dirty/mean trick on someone

literal: To raise something or someone up on the shield.
meaning: To extol, to eulogize, to boost
equivalents: To praise to the skies

literal: To raise everybody to his feet
meaning: To disturb everyone; to raise the alarm; to make everyone be more active; to rouse everyone to action.

literal: To sign something with both hands.
meaning: To willingly agree to something; to fully endorse something.

literal: With a mute.
meaning: Softly, gently; on the quiet; on the sly; without being noticed

literal: To catch someone on one’s fishing line.
meaning: By deceiving or outwitting someone to cause him to do something; to trick or to fool someone.
equivalents: To catch out

literal: To show someone where the crayfish winter
meaning: To teach someone a lesson; to punish someone; to scold someone severely.
equivalents: To make it hot for someone; to show someone a thing or two

literal: To show one’s goods from the right side.
meaning: To show a thing its best side; to make the best of something to show something to its full advantage; to display oneself in a favourable light.

literal: One lives in plenty, in affluence, in luxury
To put one’s teeth on a shelf
meaning: To go hungry; to starve.
equivalents: To tighten one’s belt

literal: To put someone on both his shoulder-blades.
meaning: To defeat an opponent in an argument, competition, contest, etc.; to beat someone.

literal: To put something under the cloth.
meaning: To delay or postpone consideration of an official paper; to pigeon-hole a request or an application; to shelve a problem or a plan

literal: To land on someone’s tongue
meaning: To become the subject of criticism.or gossip.

literal: To hit the right point
meaning: To come to the right conclusion; to come at the crux of the matter; to say or do what is exactly right as if by guessing correctly what must be said or done in the circumstances.
equivalents: To hit the nail on the head; to hit the bull’s eye/the mark

literal: To get oneself into the shchi*
meaning: To get into trouble; to be caught.
equivalents: To get/fall into the soup; to get into hot water

literal: To find oneself on someone’s little tooth
meaning: To be subjected to biting or sarcastic criticism; to become the butt of ridicule.
equivalents: To be torn to pieces

head_ru: ПОПАСТЬ HE В БРОВЬ, А В ГЛАЗ
transliteration: popast’ n’e v brov’ a v glaz
literal: To hit not the eyebrow but the eye.
meaning: To guess right; to say something that is exactly right; to give the true explanation.
equivalents: To hit the nail on the head; that hit the mark; you’ve said it!

literal: To hit the sky with one’s finger.
meaning: To say or do something that is far from - being correct or quite out of place; to answer irrelevantly.
equivalents: To get/take the wrong sow by the ear; to be wide of /way off the mark

literal: To be caught on someone’s fishing line.
meaning: To permit oneself to be fooled; to fall for a hoax or trap; to accept a proposal, an offer, etc. made to tempt one to do something.
equivalents: To swallow the bait: to rise to the fly; to be taken in; to fall into someone’s trap/snare

literal: He will not invent gunpowder.
meaning: He will never do anything remarkable or outstanding (usually said of a dull-witted, not very bright person).
equivalents: He will never set the Thames/world on fire

literal: Not enough gunpowder.
meaning: One lacks energy, strength or resolution to do something.
equivalents: It’s beyond him; he has not it in him; he is not up to it

literal: To put someone into a galosh
meaning: Put someone into an embarrassing or uncomfortable situation; to be made fun of; to get someone into a fix; to be in an awkward predicament.

literal: The last spoke in the chariot.
meaning: A person of very little importance; one who doesn’t count; a minor figure.
equivalents: A mere cog in the machine.

literal: After a little rain on a Thursday.
meaning: No one knows when.
equivalents: When pigs fly; when two Fridays come together

literal: To put a question edgewise.
meaning: To announce or state something categorically; to say something in a manner that leaves no room for doubt; to ask something directly, openly; to put a question point-blank.
equivalents: Not to mince words.

literal: To put everything on the card.
meaning: To risk all that one has on a single venture, method, etc.; to stake all one’s hopes on one source or means.
equivalents: To put all one’s eggs in one basket

literal: To put someone in a blind alley.
meaning: To bewilder, to puzzle, to nonplus someone; to throw someone into confusion.

literal: To put a cross on someone/something
meaning: To lose faith in someone or something; to stop thinking of someone or something; to give someone up for lost; to give something up as a hopeless case.
equivalents: To kiss something good-bye

literal: To put one’s hand on something
meaning: To be actively involved in something (usually reprehensible, blameworthy).
equivalents: To have/take a hand in something; to have a finger in the pie.

literal: To take for a pure coin.
meaning: To regard something as true; to take something seriously.
equivalents: To take in good faith; to take at face value

literal: To pull something up by the ears.
meaning: To make use of something without adequate grounds; to advance farfetched arguments.
equivalents: To drag something in.

literal: To collapse with a bang
meaning: To flop; to be a complete and ignominious failure.
equivalents: To come a cropper/crasher; to fall flat on one’s face.

literal: To buzz someone’s ears through.
meaning: To bore someone by telling him some- thing over and over again; to keep dinging something into someone’s ears.
equivalents: To talk someone’s ears off about something; to drone on at someone; to go rabbiting on

literal: To run through something with a red thread
meaning: To be the basic idea, the key-note, the essence of something; to run through something (e. g. a book or a speech)

literal: To walk up and down someone’s address
meaning: To make a snide remark about someone; to make fun of someone; to make an implied criticism.
equivalents: To have a fling at someone; go give someone a bad write-up

literal: To let something pass by one’s ears
meaning: To pay no attention or not to react to something that has been or is being said.

literal: To hide the ends in water.
meaning: To destroy evidence; to bury, remove every trace of something; to cover up one’s tracks.
equivalents: And no one is the wiser.

literal: Someone lacks bird’s milk.
meaning: A great abundance of everything.

literal: To eat a pood* of salt with someone
meaning: To live with or know someone for a long time; to spend a long time together with someone.

literal: To let the goat into the kitchen garden.
meaning: To give someone access to a place where he may be particularly harmful or dangerous, or to something from which he wishes to profit.

literal: You won’t breach it with a cannon-ball.
meaning: You can’t persuade him, you can’t influence him, you can’t budge him.

literal: To work with one’s sleeves rolled up.
meaning: To work assiduously, strenuously.

literal: To work without giving rest to one’s hands.
meaning: To work unceasingly, tirelessly, indefatigably.
equivalents: To be as busy as a bee

literal: To do one’s utmost, to strain every nerve,
meaning: to do next to impossible to attain one’s end.
equivalents: To lay oneself out; to go all out

literal: To hang out one’s ears
meaning: To be so carried away by what one hears that one doesn’t react properly or forgets about something important.

literal: To discharge the atmosphere.
meaning: To relieve tension; to create an atmosphere that will cool down a fiery argument.
equivalents: To clear the air

literal: To eat up kasha
meaning: To disentangle something; to put things right; to clear up a mess; to get oneself out of a mess.

literal: To tear and throw.
meaning: To get irritated; to be in a towering rage; to show angry impatience; to worry oneself into a state of temper.
equivalents: To fret and fume

literal: To tear someone into pieces.
meaning: To pester someone with questions or requests; to bother someone too much; not to give someone any peace.

literal: To roar like a beluga.
meaning: To wail; to scream; to howl with frenzy.

literal: To be born with a shirt on
meaning: To be always lucky, successful, happy.
equivalents: To always fall on one’s feet; to be born with a silver spoon in one’s mouth.

literal: One’s hand wouldn’t shake doing something.
meaning: One won’t hesitate to do something; one will do something without scruple.
equivalents: One wouldn’t think twice about doing something; without a qualm.

literal: One’s hand won’t rise.
meaning: One can’t bring himself to do something; one is hesitant about doing something.
equivalents: Not to have the heart to do something.

literal: One’s hands are short.
meaning: One doesn’t have enough authority, power or strength to do something; one is in no position to do something.
equivalents: Just try! You coudn’t if you tried!

literal: One’s hands don’t reach.
meaning: One has no time or possibility to undertake something.

literal: You can’t reach someone with your hand.
meaning: Someone is out of reach (usually said of someone in a high position).

literal: To sit down on someone’s neck
meaning: To submit someone to one’s willy; to put someone under one’s complete control; to use someone as a tool.
equivalents: To live off someone

literal: To get into someone else’s sleigh.
meaning: To undertake to do something one knows nothing about or which one who has inadequate knowledge, training, etc.; to occupy a post for which one is unsuited.

literal: We too have a moustache of our own.
meaning: Not young in wisdom; no worse than.
equivalents: We weren’t born yesterday.

literal: Soft-boiled boots.
meaning: Rot, nonsense, rubbish, a trifling matter, nothing.

literal: To smooth sharp corners.
meaning: To smooth things over; to relieve the situation; to ease tension; to adjust differences

literal: To thicken the paints.
meaning: To exaggerate; to picture something as being worse than it really is.
equivalents: To lay it on thick

literal: To relegate to the archives.
meaning: To dismiss as unfit for a particular use; to bury in oblivion as something obsolete or useless.

literal: Seven sweats have come off.
meaning: One has exerted himself to the fullest to accomplish something.
equivalents: To sweat one’s guts out

literal: Someone has seven Fridays in one week.
meaning: Someone who easily and frequently changes his mind, mood or intentions.
equivalents: Someone is in twenty minds; to chop and change

literal: sertse/dusha n’e l’ezhit
meaning: One’s heart/soul doesn’t lie for something or someone. One feels great pity, compassion, grief; one feels something keenly, takes something hard.
equivalents: To put one’s foot in it: to get oneself into a fix/spot

literal: One’s heart is breaking.
meaning: One feels great pity, compassion, grief; one feels something keenly, takes something hard.
equivalents: One’s heart is breaking.

literal: To sit down into a puddle.
meaning: To get oneself into an awkward position or compromising situation; to let oneself be duped; to do or say something stupid.
equivalents: To put one’s foot in it: to get oneself into a fix/spot.

literal: To sit between two chairs
meaning: To try to adhere to two different, irreconcilable points of view: to try to keep the favour of both sides in a dispute
equivalents: To run with the hare and hunt with the hounds; to play a double game.

literal: To sit on one’s suitcasesю
meaning: Packed and waiting to go.

literal: To sit with one’s arms folded.
meaning: To be idle; to sit still doing nothing.
equivalents: To sit twiddling one’s thumbs

literal: To decline someone in all cases.
meaning: To talk a lot about someone at every opportunity (usually in a derogatory manner).

literal: So many summers, so many winters!
meaning: How long ago! (A greeting used when two people haven’t seen each other for a long time).
equivalents: Long time no see! I haven’t seen you for ages! Fancy meeting you after all this time.

literal: A weak string.
meaning: The most vulnerable aspect of someone’s character; a matter upon which one is easily affected or most sensitive.
equivalents: A weak/soft point

literal: From the light hand of someone.
meaning: At someone’s initiative or following someone’s example which set in motion a series of subsequent actions or deeds.

literal: Someone’s footprints have grown cold.
meaning: Someone has run away, disappeared; there’s not a trace of someone.
equivalents: To vanish into thin air.

literal: One could hear a fly flying past.
meaning: It’s absolutely quiet; it’s deadly still.
equivalents: You could hear a pin drop

literal: Saliva is flowing.
meaning: Someone is anxious to partake of some tasty food or drink.
equivalents: To make someone’s mouth water

literal: To look through both.
meaning: To look attentively; to be closely observant; to be on the alert; to be particularly watchful
equivalents: To keep one’s eyes peeled/skinned

literal: To look someone in the mouth.
meaning: To listen attentively and servilely to what one says; to fawn on someone.
equivalents: To hang on someone’s words

head_ru: СМОТРЕТЬ КАК БАРАН НА НОВЫЕ ВОРОТА
transliteration: smotret’ kak baran na novyye vorota
literal: To look at someone or something like a ram at a new gate.
meaning: To look at someone or something with a puzzled, perplexed or dismayed expression on one s face; to look rather stupid, not understanding what is going on; to look quite lost.

literal: To take the shavings off someone.
meaning: To criticize someone severely, to rate someone soundly, to scold someone.
equivalents: To tear someone off a strip.

literal: One has eaten the dog at something.
meaning: One has acquired great skill or experience in something; one knows something thoroughly; one is an expert in something.
equivalents: To have something at one’s fingertips; to know something inside out; to know the ropes; he’s been around

literal: The dream has come into one’s hand.
meaning: Said of a dream that has come true.

literal: With a creak.
meaning: To do something very slowly, with great difficulty or effort, reluctantly.

literal: With an open heart/soul
meaning: To treat, someone or do something sincerely, trustfully, frankly, openly, without prejudice.

literal: To sleep without one’s hind legs.
meaning: To sleep soundly.
equivalents: To sleep like a log/top

literal: Off one’s shoulders.
meaning: One needn’t bother about something any longer; one no longer has an irksome burden to bear; one has got rid of duties, cares, responsibilities.
equivalents: That’s done, thank goodness.

literal: To mix up all the cards.
meaning: To spoil or ruin someone’s plans; to upset someone’s calculations.
equivalents: To upset someone’s apple-cart.

literal: To fight against the windmills.
meaning: To waste energy in combating imaginary evils or difficulties; to attack an imaginary foe.
equivalents: To tilt at windmills.

literal: To put something in the vertex of an angle.
meaning: To assign primary importance to something; to consider something to be indispensible.

literal: To put someone on his feet.
meaning: To cure someone of an illness.

literal: To put someone on the same board with someone else.
meaning: To put someone on the same level with someone else; to consider one person comparable with another.

head_ru: СТАВИТЬ что-либо С НОГ НА ГОЛОВУ
literal: To put something from its feet into its head.
meaning: To give a distorted picture of something; to put things in the wrong order; to take the effect for the cause.
equivalents: To put the cart before the horse

literal: To put dots above the i’s
meaning: To make something clear and definite; to give most careful attention to detail.
equivalents: To put the finishing touches to; to dot one’s i’s and cross one’s t’s.

literal: As old as the world.
meaning: Very old, stale, uninteresting because heard before.
equivalents: As old as the hills

literal: To grind off the edges.
meaning: To remove differences or distinctions.

transliteration: One stands as if dug in.
literal: One stands as if dug in.
meaning: One stands quite still, motionless.
equivalents: To stand as if rooted to the ground.

literal: To stand for someone or something like a mountain.
meaning: To defend someone or something with all one’s might, by every possible means; to be solidly behind someone or something; to stand firm or stick up for someone or something.
equivalents: To stand for someone through thick and thing; to back someone up to the hilt.

literal: To stand over someone’s soul.
meaning: To annoy someone by constantly watching him; to importune someone.
equivalents: To stand over someone; to breath down someone’s neck; to worry the life out of someone.

literal: To stand across someone’s throat.
meaning: To become unbearable, unendurable; to be a source of annoyance, irritation, especially a persistent one.
equivalents: A thorn in one’s flesh/side.

literal: To stand across the road.
meaning: To be an obstacle, hindrance or impediment to someone; to hamper someone’s chances of success or progress.
equivalents: To be stand in someone’s way

literal: A sparrow that has been shot at.
meaning: A person experienced in the matter at hand; someone not easily deceived.
equivalents: An old hand; a knowing old bird

literal: To fire a cannon at sparrows.
meaning: To use an instrument or take measures far more powerful than is necessary; to make a great effort for a small gain.
equivalents: To use a sledge-hammer to crack a nut; to break a fly/butterfly up on the wheel.

literal: To cut everyone’s hair with one comb.
meaning: To treat everyone alike; to reduce everyone to the same level; to judge all people the same way.

literal: To count the crows.
meaning: To gape at something; to be distracted, inattentive; to be bored.

literal: To dance from the stove.
meaning: To begin with something that is elementary, familiar, or simpler, repeating all the movements or operations from the very beginning; to begin from the beginning.

literal: To pull someone by the ears.
meaning: To do everything to help someone (usually one who is remiss and of less than average ability) in his studies, in obtaining promotion, etc.

literal: A warm little place.
meaning: A highly paid appointment or job; a profitable position.
equivalents: A cushy/snug job

literal: Quieter than water, lower than grass.
meaning: One is meek, timid, mild, quiet.
equivalents: Quiet as a mouse; meek as a lamb.

literal: To pound the water in the mortar.
meaning: To do useless work, to engage in fruitless talk that can have no results, to waste time.
equivalents: To beat the air; to mill the wind.

literal: To burst at the seams.
meaning: To be on the verge of destruction, collapse, ruin.
equivalents: To go/fall to pieces; to fall/burst apart at the seams.

literal: Heavy artillery.
meaning: Something that can be used in an emergency as an effective means of achieving an end.

literal: t’azhol na pod’yom
meaning: Heavy on the rise. Slow or unwilling to do something; sluggish, hard to move or rouse to action.

literal: To drag the time.
meaning: To be slow in acting; to procrastinate; to wait for a favourable opportunity.
equivalents: To bide one’s time

literal: To pull someone by the tongue.
meaning: To make someone say something; to pump someone.

literal: To kill two hares.
meaning: To achieve two objects simultaneously; to attain two results with one means.
equivalents: To kill two birds with one stone.

literal: To strike as if with an axe-butt on the head.
meaning: To amaze, to perplex, to stun someone; to take someone aback.
equivalents: To knock someone down with a feather; to knock someone off his pins.

literal: To go into the scrubs.
meaning: To withdraw from one’s promise or an undertaking; to disclaim further responsibility for something.
equivalents: To make oneself scarce; to back out; to show the white feather.

literal: To go headlong into something.
meaning: To be fully absorbed, deeply engrossed or totally involved in something.
equivalents: To throw oneself/plunge into something; to get up to one’s neck in something.

literal: To carry away one’s legs.
meaning: To flee; to run as fast as one’s legs will carry one: to have a narrow escape.
equivalents: To escape by the skin of one’s teeth.

literal: To wipe someone’s nose.
meaning: To win an advantage over someone; to humiliate or cause disgruntlement; to make a clever retort.
equivalents: To score off someone; to get the better of someone; to steal a march on someone.

literal: Something cuts one’s ear.
meaning: It’s grating upon one’s ears; it’s painful to listen to; it offends the ear.

literal: One’s ears fade.
meaning: It is so ridiculous, absurd or silly that it’s disgusting to listen to.
equivalents: It makes one sick to hear about it

literal: To snatch the stars from the sky.
meaning: To be very good at something; to be able to do something remarkable.
equivalents: He is as good as they come

literal: To clutch one’s head.
meaning: To be struck with horror; to abandon oneself to despair.

literal: To walk round and about.
meaning: To avoid saying something openly, frankly, directly; to avoid the essential facts; not to come to the point; to approach a matter in a roundabout way.
equivalents: To beat about the bush

literal: To walk on one’s head.
meaning: To get into mischief; to play pranks; to be naughty (usually said of children).

literal: Who cares whether or not the grass grows.
meaning: One couldn’t care less; it’s all the same to someone.
equivalents: Not to care a straw

literal: You could even roll a ball through it.
meaning: There’s nothing there; it’s completely empty.
equivalents: Bare as a bone; as bare as the palm of one’s hand.

literal: To limp on both legs;
meaning: To have serious gaps in one’s knowledge, training or abilities.

literal: Thin as a matchstick.
meaning: Very thin.

literal: There’s no price on someone or something
meaning: Someone or something is priceless, invaluable.

literal: One teaspoonful every other hour.
meaning: To be few and at long intervals; very slowly.
equivalents: In drops; in/by driblets; few and far between

literal: A black cat has run between them.
meaning: There’s a coolness between them; they have become estranged.
equivalents: They have fallen out

literal: Miracles in a sieve.
meaning: It’s amazing, incredible, unbelievable extraordinary; it’s a fantastic tale.

literal: To bank up the fire with someone else’s hands.
meaning: To benefit by the results of someone else’s work; to use the results of someone else’s work to achieve one’s selfish ends.
equivalents: To make a cat’s-paw of someone; to pull someone’s chestnuts out of the fire.

literal: We’ll pelt you (him, etc.) with our caps.
meaning: We expect to win without difficulty; it’s as good as certain (to boast of an easy victory).
equivalents: It’s a walk-over; it’s in the bag

literal: A cap acquaintance.
meaning: A slight acquaintance.
equivalents: A nodding/bowing acquaintance

literal: It is sewn with white thread.
meaning: It is a flimsy story or excuse easily seen through; it is all too obvious; it is quite transparent.
equivalents: Something does not hold water; made up out of whole cloth.

literal: No room for an apple to fall.
meaning: Used to indicate that there is a large number of people in one place, that the place is overcrowded, that there is hardly room to move or turn around.
equivalents: There’s no room to swing a cat

literal: One’s tongue is hung well.
meaning: Someone is a smooth talker; someone has a glib tongue.
equivalents: To have the gift of the gab.
